fields.label: Seen from an extremely low angle, the façade of St Mark's Basilica in Venice with its four famous bronze horses rises majestically in dark blue and gold across the full height of the upright format. The elaborate architecture of the façade's central section is cropped by the image thereby alluding to its physical and historical grandeur. Walter Sickert visited Venice four times between 1895 and 1904. There are at least six other versions of this composition and it has been suggested that he had seen Monet's famous series of the façade of Rouen Cathedral, in Paris, while traveling to Venice for the first time. Monet had famously depicted the cathedral in changing light settings, resulting in a different colour range in each canvas.

fields.artist: maker's mark: RC over a pheon (barbed arrowhead), London.
fields.label: This cup and cover were bequeathed to St Werburgh's in 1624 by Dr Thomas White, uncle of Mrs Humphrey Brown. They were clearly intended to complement the three Brown pieces and to supersede the cup of 1554–1555 (still in existence) which would have been considered oldfashioned in the context of the re-furbishing of the church in the 1620s.
fields.source: Lent by the Diocese of Bristol.

fields.additional_information:
The sitter's sumptuous clothes reflect his high status and he wears the chain of the exclusive Order of St Michael, with its pendant showing the archangel Michael vanquishing the Devil. The oval cameo on his hat bears an image of the Roman goddess Venus, suggestive of the vanquishing power of love, whereas the sword clasped in his right hand alludes to more military conquests.

The identity of the artist remains unknown, but he was clearly connected well enough to secure commissions from the French elite.
fields.label: The gentleman depicted in this detailed portrait is probably Odet de Foix, Vicomte de Lautrec (1485-1528), a French nobleman and military leader. This identification was made thanks to Jean Clouet's drawing of the Vicomte in the Musée Condé, Chantilly.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: Portrait of a Nobleman wearing the Order of St Michael

fields.additional_information: n/a
fields.label: The gentleman in this small painting has not been identified. He is attired in an unpretentious brown coat and cap. He looks directly at the viewer and his features are painted with great naturalism and sensitivity. The precise attention to detail is no doubt owed to Corneille's origins and training in the Netherlands.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946

fields.additional_information: The growing wealth of the Netherlands in the seventeenth century was dependent largely on the Republic?s maritime trade, fishing and whaling. While seascape painting celebrated this success story, the images also held deeper symbolic meaning. They warned the viewer to be mindful of the challenges to a moral and happy life, in the same way as a ship is in constant danger at sea. Jan Theunisz Blanckerhoff, who died young, was influenced by one of the leading seascape painters of his era, Ludolf Bakhuizen, to whom this picture was once attributed
fields.label: Seascape painting was one of the unique achievements of seventeenth century Dutch art. Here, Dutch ships, so-called men-of-war, are seen sailing in a stiff breeze and under scattered sunlight off a distant coastline.
fields.source: Presented by Miss M.C.F. Smith, 1949

fields.additional_information:
The largest vessel is the State Yacht and the figure in red on its deck is the Archduke Leopold Wilhelm, Governor of the Spanish Netherlands. Next to him, in black, is Don Gaspar de Bracamonte y Guzmán, a Spanish diplomat. 

The Flemish painter Bonaventura Peeters specialised in marine and landscape painting and worked in Antwerp. The painting may have been commissioned by someone who had attended the celebrations in an official capacity. The composition is unusually wide compared to its height. This may indicate that the painting was intended to be hung above a door.
fields.label: This painting shows the celebrations in Antwerp at the end of the Thirty Years' War in 1648. Cannons are being fired from land and water, crowds are on the shore, and a flotilla of ships brimming with passengers sails towards the city.
fields.source: Accepted by HM Government in lieu of Inheretance Tax and allocated to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, 2010
fields.title_of_object: Shipping on the Schelde off Antwerp

fields.additional_information: Although the wildlife is exotic, including an elephant and a camel, the detailed landscape and buildings in the background of this painting recall the countryside near Venice. Venetian artist Giovanni Mansueti was a pupil of Gentile Bellini and, like his master, painted a number of large narrative paintings for Venetian confraternities (a Christian association of lay people promoting charity). The smaller scale of this painting indicates that it was probably intended for a domestic setting.
fields.label: According to Christian legend, when he was in the wilderness St Jerome removed a thorn from a lion's paw. For this kindness, the lion became his faithful companion. St Jerome's compassion towards the creature was interpreted as an act of Christian charity.
fields.source: The Bequest of FPM. Schiller, 1946

fields.additional_information: The strong colours are deliberately limited in their range and the gold background is used to enhance the expressive outline of the figures. There is a striking naturalism and touching humanity in the way that Mary embraces her dead son and St John, in the foreground, adoringly raises his arms. Taddeo Gaddi was a pupil and collaborator of Giotto and one of the most influential painters of fourteenth-century Florence.
fields.label: This small panel was probably made for private devotion. In the upper portion appears the Crucifixion, with the Virgin, St John the Evangelist and Mary Magdalen. Over the crucifix is set a pelican, symbolic of Christ's sacrifice (as the pelican was supposed to draw blood from her chest to feed her young). In the lower portion is a lamentation over the body of the dead Christ.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund, 1959

fields.additional_information: The paint medium is made up of pigments mixed with egg tempera. Tempera is fast-drying and was applied quickly in parallel strokes with any under-colour showing between the lines, as in the robe of the angel on the right. The paint was laid on a brilliant white absorbent ground of gesso made largely from gypsum. Under-drawing was often incised or, as here, painted on. Where the red has faded from St John the Baptist's robe (on the right) the fluent but precise drawing is very obvious. The areas to be covered in gold leaf were first painted with a red clay base, which is now quite visible, and decorative patterns for the haloes were punched after the gilding. Powdered gold patterns were also applied to the borders of robes and, here, also to the Virgin's under-dress. The gold has been rubbed away but the raised mordant pattern can still be seen.
fields.label: In the past this painting of the Virgin and Saints has been extensively restored. Not only had it been scorched by the flames of devotional candles, but it may have also been attacked by someone as there are slashes in the area of the Christ Child's head and St Anthony's robe. The panel was probably made by the Florentine artist Lorenzo di Niccolò to adorn a side altar in a church. The main inscription recalls the Angel Gabriel's salutation to the Virgin.
fields.source: The Bequest of C. ML Wickham through the National Art - Collections Fund (110w The Art Fund)
fields.title_of_object: The Virgin and Child with Saints Paul, Peter, Anthony Abbot and John the Baptist

fields.label: A quiet, watery scene is populated with only a small number of solemn figures and buildings. The damp climate of the vast Venetian Lagoon is tangible in the crumbling plaster of the humble boathouses and shipyards in the foreground. Beyond, the Tower of Malghera and the skyline of Venice appear in the slightly hazy sunlight. The artist and his uncle Giovanni Antonio Canal, commonly called Canaletto, collected motifs from the atmospheric Lagoon on a trip to Padua in 1741. This imaginary or capriccio painting and the Tower of Malghera are in fact based on compositions by Canaletto, but the young artist was soon to lead his own successful career as court painter in Dresden, Vienna and Warsaw.
fields.source: Accepted by HM Government in lieu of Inheritance Tax and allocated to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, 1988

fields.label: This sensitive double portrait of a mother and child used to hang at Powderham Castle in Devon. Lady Honywood was the eldest daughter of William Courtenay, 2nd Earl of Devon and the portrait was probably painted as a gift to her family after she had settled with her husband Sir John Honywood in Kent. The portrait is noted in 1784 in Sir Joshua Reynolds's pocket book where he would make appointments for sittings. It was exhibited at the Royal Academy that year, where it was acclaimed by the art critics of the day. Reynolds is at his most subtle in this intimate study of a mother and daughter on a grand scale. He has cleverly contrasted the ruddiness of the child's complexion and shiny hair with her mother's rouged cheeks and powdered hair. The pose is unusual, showing the mother's tender support for her child as she takes tentative steps while looking confidently back at the viewer
fields.source: Accepted by HM Government in lieu of Inberitance Tax and allocated to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, 2011
fields.title_of_object: Frances Courtenay, Lady Honywood (b.1763) and her Daughter

fields.label:
Storm clouds are closing in on the evening sun in this composition. The Temple of Minerva Medica, Rome, is fancifully set on a coast which recalls the Bay of Baia near Naples. A sailing ship is seeking to escape the wind and in the foreground fishermen are hauling in a rowing boat.
Claude-Joseph Vernet, the leading French landscape and marine painter of the later 18th century, lived in Rome as a young man. Vernet's notebooks record that his clients there included Grand Tourists and French dignitaries. In 1746 the French ambassador to the Vatican Frédéric-Jérôme de la Rochefoucauld de Roye commissioned Vernet to paint this scene and its pendant, contrasting evening storm and morning calm. The second painting is now in the Minneapolis Institute of Arts. The 'missing lower corners of the composition are an original feature in both paintings, here covered with a slip frame. This indicates that the pictures were probably commissioned with a specific location in mind where they may have fitted into existing panelling.
fields.source: Conservation of this painting was made possible thanks to a generous donation from Terence Mordaunt, through Bristol Museums Development Trust.   Purchased, 1969
fields.title_of_object: Genoa Lighthouse and the Temple of Minerva Medica

fields.label:
The face of the gentleman captured in this portrait is brightly lít, emphasising his strong features. He holds the viewer's gaze. The plain background and his brown coat further enhance his command beyond the picture frame.
The artist signed and dated the picture, yet little is known about George Beare. His date of birth is unknown but he was working in Salisbury by 1746 and died near Andover in 1749. Only forty-six portraits have been recorded as painted by him. Many of his sitters are members of the Hampshire gentry and the professional middle-class. He painted with sensitivity and a strong insight into character. Beare may have trained in London, and was certainly familiar with the portraiture of William Hogarth.
fields.source: Purchased, 1954
fields.title_of_object: Portrait of a Man in Brown

fields.label: This sensitive portrait of Catherine Sardou, wife of François Bruguière, is an outstanding early work by Antoine-Jean Gros, who is now best remembered for vast canvases that helped create the popular image of Napoleon as a great warrior and leader. This composition concentrates our attention on Madame Bruguière's eyes and wistful expression, revealing her character more than a mere society portrait. In 1793 Antoine-Jean Gros left France for Italy, where he spent the next eight years. The portraits of Catherine Bruguière and her husband, François, number among many works which Gros painted in Genoa. In the pendant, François, ship owner and president of the French chamber of commerce in Genoa, is presented as a supporter of revolutionary France. Around the time he painted these portraits, Gros met Josephine Bonaparte in Genoa, an auspicious meeting which led to his later acquaintance with Napoleon and his establishment as a leading artist.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of The Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund and the Penraven Bequest, 1967

fields.medium: Video animation, with music by Yu Din, 10 minutes, 2010
fields.label: "...the title Last Post is the military music as well as a reference to the departure of the English from China."       The reference to China is to the Opium Wars when the drug was illegally smuggled from Bengal into China. The opium paid for the import of tea to Britain, and the wars led to Hong Kong coming under British rule. The video makes a link to the British Raj in India. A Company Man', French horn and gopi hairpieces are moving motifs. The perspective of a Mughal terrace is collapsed. The soundtrack wells up into techno beats that reach a climax: the sound of disintegration.
fields.source: Presented by the Art Fund under Art Fund International

fields.label: The man reading his Instruction Manual merges with the manual in a play on 'man' and 'manual that seems to mock masculine attachment to rulebooks. Tala Madani's painting is as dark as Northern Renaissance paintings that attempt to visualise hell and as darkly humorous as satires attacking corrupt politicians. Our pleasure in the painted surface is mingled with our recoil from the violence the paint so sensuously evokes.
fields.source: Presented by the Art Fund, under Art Fund International.

fields.label: The colours in this accomplished still life are muted but relieved by the sharp notes of the lemons in the right foreground and the warmth of the pears behind. It is the oysters on the left which dominate the composition. Their succulent cream and white flesh and freshly-opened shells are painted with a panache that Boudin was later to use in his more familiar seaside scenes. Eugène Boudin probably painted this still life just a few years after he gave up his stationery business and went to Paris to train as an artist. The composition and subject matter - a table laden with fruit, nuts, glassware, and oysters on a platter - demonstrate Boudin's study of seventeenth century Dutch still-life paintings. On the other hand, his relatively free handling of the paint shows his stylistic affinity with the contemporary Barbizon School painters.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund, 1970

fields.medium: Oil on paper laid down on canvas
fields.label:
It was probably the artist's intention that we cannot identify the woman at the piano whose back is turned to the viewer, nor her companion whose blurred features are shown in profile. Although Eugène Carrière often used his family members as models, as a leading Symbolist he painted them as a microcosm of humanity, the subject of his picture relating universal human relationships. The almost monochromatic grey palette and soft focus contribute to the naturalistic recreation of light, space and colour.
Eugène Carrière's early work was influenced by Rubens and Velazquez but he later gave up the use of colour. The monochrome works of his final period were greatly admired by the sculptor Rodin who recognised Carrière's mastery of tone in the way that he modelled forms without the distraction of colour.
Designed by Emile Gallé.
fields.source: Given by Mr E T. Love, 1950.

fields.label: In this sombre evening landscape, the setting sun illuminates a cloudy sky, but the trees silhouetted against the low horizon and meadows by a river in the foreground are already cast in darkness. Only the tranquil water itself catches and reflects some of the last, cold sunlight. In an atmosphere of silent calm, cows are led to drink, while a small boat glides towards the shore. Nature itself is both the inspiration and the subject of this painting, rather than providing the backdrop to a narrative. Karl Daubigny was taught by his father, the well-known Barbizon School landscape painter Charles François Daubigny. Like him, Karl found his subjects in the Fontainbleau forest, near Paris. The painting is executed on a thin wood panel and was probably begun outdoors (en plein air) and finished later in the artist's studio.
fields.source: Bequest of Mrs M.A.M. Sheldon, 1999

fields.label: From 1859 Courbet often stayed on the Normandy coast to paint ‘sea landscapes', as he called them, although they were largely produced in the studio. In this painting a beach is depicted at low tide. The view stretches out across a calm sea to the low horizon. The scene shows neither a specific location nor a particular point of interest, yet it conveys a sense of monumentality. In contrast to the Impressionists, who were to use white canvases, Courbet worked in the traditional manner upon a dark ground which here intensifies the melancholy mood. He explained: “nature, without the sun, is also dark and black. I do as the light does, I illuminate the parts that project, and the picture is done”. The realist painter Courbet is best known for his paintings of contemporary life.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the National Art-Collections Fund (now The Art Fund), 1952

fields.label: ‘Sunset' is one of the many ‘croquetons' (little sketches) Seurat painted in the region around Paris in the early 1880s. They are predominantly landscapes, painted directly onto cigar-box lids. Such lids were easy to carry and the red-brown colour of the wood provided a warm ground ideally suited to landscape subjects. In his paintings Seurat sought ‘an optical formula' by which to discipline his work. Here he has tentatively begun to use the theory of complementary colours. In the foreground of the field with its fruit trees and low buildings beyond, touches of blue are juxtaposed with their complementary colour, a deep orange. This gives a far more vibrant and luminous effect than could have been achieved by the artist mixing his colours on the palette. The clouds over the horizon take up a lighter orange glow.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund and donations from Bristol citizens, 1963

fields.label: In this small landscape the eye-level is just above the ground. A field of artichokes stretches into the background and the large plants in the foreground dwarf the scenery and a figure in the behind. Norman Garstin settled in Newlyn, Cornwall in 1886 and he became the intellectual mentor of the Newlyn School of artists. This early work was painted at Hyères in the South of France in 1883. Garstin had just spent several years studying in Paris and he had a highly developed appreciation of French painting and Japanese prints. This may explain Garstin’s choice of a radical composition and perspective. In 1884 he wrote of Edouard Manet: 'He lets in light and air. Pictures like his later ones amongst the brown bitumen canvas of the average exhibition seem like patches of sunlight on a prison wall'.
fields.source: Given by the Contemporary Art Society, 1980

fields.label: This view shows a coastal landscape with rolling hills and hedges. The water can be glimpsed in the background as well as a few simple white buildings on the right. After studying in France, Garstin travelled through Southern Europe and North Africa, painting along the way. The bright sunlight, colours and exotic plants show the artist’s interest in including new modes of seeing and new subject matter into his landscapes. This small panel was given to the Contemporary Art Society by the artist’s daughter, herself a painter, and later given to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery.
fields.source: Given by the Contemporary Art Society, 1980

fields.label: This coastal scene shows a rearing white horse carrying a rider, who is holding a green standard like a medieval knight. Looking out to sea beyond the shoreline the water is placid. Two ships frame the composition on either side. This is not an illustration of a well-known literary, mythological or religious narrative. Although the brushstrokes are bold and the palette is light and atmospheric, Redon also clearly rejected the Impressionists' style and subject matter. He regarded their work as only an extreme form of naturalism and considered them to be slaves of the visual world. His own pictorial world was mystical and imaginative and for almost twenty years he even rejected colour and created dreamlike, symbolist images in charcoal and monochrome prints. In his later years he returned to a celebratory use of colour as can be seen in this work.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund, 1964
fields.title_of_object: Rider on the Beach with Two Ships

fields.label: Vuillard painted many portraits of Madame Hessel but here he has stepped back to show her in a relaxed domestic setting. The furniture and contemporary paintings on the wall show a fashionable drawing room. The large dog provides a compositional link between the expanse of floor and the sofa and, with its wagging tail, animates the scene. Lucie Hessel, wife of the art dealer Jos Hessel, was a close friend of the artist. Vuillard dined every evening at the couple's Paris apartment and often stayed in their country homes. Vuillard's harmonious colour scheme was achieved by his choice of materials. The picture was painted directly onto unprimed cardboard, its warm mid-tone often left untouched by any pigment. The surface of the cardboard is visible in all areas of the painting, particularly in the sofa and the floor.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the National-Art Collections Fund (now The Art Fund) and the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund, 1961
fields.title_of_object: Interior with Madame Hessel and her Dog

fields.additional_information: The musical theme of the painting seems suggestive of lovemaking. This is hinted at in the voluptuously shaped instrument resting on the knee of the lady on the right, and more overtly illustrated by the amorous couple on the left. The inscribed date 1631 is compatible with the style of dress of the fashionable lady at the centre with her back to the spectator. It was not unusual for an artist to repeat a successful composition and several versions and variations of this picture exist, including one in the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.
fields.label: This image of a musical party was painted during a short-lived fashion in seventeenth century Holland for pictures of elegantly dressed men and women gathering indoors. It is signed by the Amsterdam artist Pieter Codde, who is particularly associated with this type of picture.
fields.source: Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: Dutch  Cavaliers and their Ladies making Music

fields.additional_information:
Here, Jesus is shown alone and the viewer is confronted directly with his suffering and humility. Multiple versions of this deliberately simple composition by the Spanish artist exist. It remains to be confirmed if this picture was painted by Murillo himself or a member of his studio.

Bartolomé Esteban Murillo was a leading Spanish baroque painter and popular with nineteenth century audiences across Europe. This painting has been in England since at least 1857 when it was shown at the Art Treasures Exhibition in Manchester.
fields.label: Ecce homo (“behold the man") are the Latin words used by the Roman prefect Pontius Pilate in the New Testament, when he presents Jesus Christ, bound and crowned with thorns, to a hostile crowd shortly before his Crucifixion. The scene has been widely depicted in Christian art.
fields.source: On loan from a private collection.

fields.additional_information: Battle of the Saints   Podcast producers Vanessa and Tayo reveal the painting's connection with slavery and links with other objects in the museum, around the legacies of British colonial rule.   UNCOMFORTABLE TRUTHS
fields.label: The name Saints comes from the group of islands between Dominica and Guadeloupe where this famous naval battle was won over the French. It took place in 1782 and gave Britain a stronger position in the peace negotiations at the end of the American War of Independence. The artist depicts the French defeat, with the Ville de Paris surrendering in the centre, her sails unmanageable, while the Glorieux is shown dismasted in the foreground. Pocock managed to compose what must have been a chaotic scene into one in which the viewer can clearly read the action. Nicholas Pocock enjoyed a successful career as an artist in Bristol and then London, carving out a niche for himself as a painter of ships and sea battles. He admired the 17th century Dutch marine painter Willem Van de Velde, and the President of the Royal Academy Sir Joshua Reynolds encouraged him to seek out other artists, especially Claude-Joseph Vernet. Pocock learnt how to make sophisticated but accurate compositions from Vernet's ability to unite landscape with nautical painting.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund and the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1981
fields.title_of_object: The Close of the Battle of the Saints

fields.label: The subject of this vast landscape composition is taken from Roman literature. In Ovid's Metamorphoses', Callisto, one of Diana's nymphs, was seduced by Jupiter. The painting shows the moment when Diana confronts the pregnant nymph. All the depicted scenery is based on the countryside around Rome where Richard Wilson had spent nearly five years in the 1750s. However, the ruinous round tower, although familiar in Italian landscapes, is actually Dolbadarn Castle, seen as it stands on its crag at the foot of Snowdon in North Wales. Richard Wilson was the first British-born artist to make a full-time career as a landscape painter and was encouraged to persevere by the French painter Claude-Joseph Vernet. This is one of a set of four classical landscapes painted for Henry Blundell of Ince Hall, Lancashire; the others remain at the Hall. Much of the preliminary work on these large canvases was painted by Wilson's apprentices.
fields.source: Purchased. 1955

fields.label: The Simplon Pass is a high mountain pass in the Alps. It connects Brig in Switzerland with Domodossola in Piedmont, Italy. Until the 17th century it was mainly traversed by smugglers and mercenaries. By 1805 a road had been constructed at the direction of the emperor Napoleon. From then on the pass was usable by post carriage. After the Napoleonic Wars British tourists would have taken this route and William West's dramatic upright view of the sublime mountain scenery would have appealed to real and armchair travellers alike.
fields.source: Presented by Alfred Edmund Hudd, 1905

fields.label: This study shows the park of Malvern Hall with the house immersed in the trees and barely visible in the distance. A summer storm has brought heavy rain-filled clouds into the tall blue sky. In July 1809, John Constable spent a fortnight at Malvern Hall in Warwickshire where he had been commissioned to paint a portrait. At that date he was earning a little by painting portraits, while devoting his free time to studying the landscape in accordance with his famous resolution to be a ‘natural painter'. This oil sketch is one of several studies painted in the fields around the house. There are considerable areas of overpaint in the upper sections of sky and this outdoor sketch may have been 'finished' by another artist after Constable’s death.
fields.source: Accepted by HM Government in lieu of Inheritance Tax and allocated to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, 1994

fields.medium: Pencil, watercolour and wash on paper
fields.label: Shahzia Sikander takes a monumental approach to traditional Indo-Persian miniature painting. "Miniature' actually refers to the minium oxide pigment used in traditional painting rather than the size of the work. At the centre of the composition a British East India Company Man faces an Indian yogi figure. The artist uses the figures as types to symbolise the colonial era opposites of Britain and India. The layered surface of Sikander's drawing stages a confrontation between 'East' and West': the effect is a visual break with the colonial culture represented by Sikander's Company Man.
fields.source: Presented by the Art Fund under Art Fund Internationa

fields.additional_information:
Ai Weiwei
 A Ton of Tea
 Installing in the gallery a monumental art work of this great weight is complex, so as to ensure no person is hurt nor the building damaged. That installation has been made possible thanks to donations from our visitors, through Bristol Museums Development Trust, and with the generous support of the Friends of Bristol Museums, Galleries & Archives.
fields.label: Ai Weiwei belongs to the first generation of artists in China that was able to create 'experimental' (Conceptual) art after the Cultural Revolution. In the 1980s Ai lived illegally in New York, surrounded by the American art that would help him to marry theory with politics in his own work. A Ton of Tea brings together many of Ai's interests in a postMinimal and richly scented giant cube of tea. The apparent simplicity of form and material makes reference to post-war art history and globalisation, through the humble substance of tea, China's oldest export.
fields.source: Presented by the Art Fund, under Art Fund International

fields.label:
"...one of a good many which I did during the fifties and early sixties which derived from what you can call "industrial" subject matter, le any urban place. Perhaps you can say that it was one of the most substantial atternpts to solve certain pictorial problems."
Although she claimed never to have painted an abstract painting Prunella Clough's industrial scenes - factories, gravel pits - appear almost as abstract mediations on form. Here the figure becomes part of the larger pattern of the wall. Friends describe how Clough photographed and collected detritus in London's North End Road to use in her painting
fields.source: Purchased, 1969

fields.label: Spencer 'Freddy' Gore and Walter Sickert formed the Camden Town Group in 1911, painting everyday scenes of working life. This intimate view of an anonymous naked woman was painted in Mornington Crescent. The way the figure is painted is dramatically different to female nudes in 19th century paintings who were usually characters from mythology or legend, their bodies idealized.
fields.source: Purchased. 1950

fields.label: A chef is depicted sitting at a simple table in the foreground reaching down to the floor to pick up a wine bottle. The handling and palette of this small painting reflects Théodule Ribot's admiration for Courbet and other French Realist painters. However, the subject of the young cook staring at us brazenly whilst helping himself to the bottle, unaware of being observed by his colleagues and the irony that the bottle is indeed empty, was intended to amuse. Kitchen scenes were also the subject of several paintings which Théodule Ribot, who was self-taught, had accepted for the Paris Salon in 1861. He achieved recognition and was presented with a special award at the Paris Exposition Universelle as well as the Légion d'honneur in 1878.
fields.source: Presented by Alfred Aaron de Pass, 1936

fields.label: Juliette Récamier (1777–1849) was a celebrated beauty and hostess of great wit and charm. Her salon - an elegant reception room where the famous and fashionable gathered - attracted many of the political and literary figures of early 19th-century Paris. This is regarded as one of the best portraits of her. The original marble bust, made in 1805 or 1806, is in Lyon, where both sitter and artist were born. It was very popular and copies were made for many years.
fields.source: Given by Captain Ed. Lowndes, 1947

fields.medium: Oil on paper laid down on canvas
fields.label: This tranquil study of a woodland glade in the Fontainbleau area, near Paris was painted very early in Corot's career. The scene with its trees captured loosely in a variety of rich greens was sketched directly from nature onto paper. The training of young painters in France at that time stressed the importance of such an 'étude', a rapidly painted oil study showing a fluidity of brushwork not seen in the finished work. But studies of this type were not regarded as works of art in their own right until much later in the 19th century. Many of Corot's small oil studies, including this one, remained in his studio until his death. The stamp of his posthumous sale can be seen on the bottom left.
fields.source: Purchased in recognition of the service of Arnold Wilson, Director of the Art Gallery 1968-1987, with the assistance of the National Art Collections Fund (Vera and Aileen Woodroffe Bequest) (now The Art Fund), and the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery

fields.label: Despite its small format, this warm coastal scene captures a wide-angled view of the bay at Cagnes-sur-Mer. The scene is sweeping deeply into the background, where small white buildings can just be seen. The artist had moved to the Mediterranean in 1907. X-rays reveal, though, that Renoir had originally intended the canvas for a landscape with a close-up view of houses on the right. This painting originally belonged to the art dealer Margraf & Co, a company owned by the Jewish couple Rosa and Jakob Oppenheimer. The picture later came into the possession of the Jewish chemical engineer Leopold Moller. Moller fled from the Nazi regime to England in 1939 and managed to bring the Renoir and two other paintings with him - unframed, in his suitcase, convincing customs that they were not original works of art.
fields.source: Bequest of Leopold Moller to the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1999 and presented by them, 2001

fields.label: British painter Stanhope Forbes, who was one of the leading members of the Newlyn School, painted this beach scene on the spot using a flat-ended brush, known as the square-brush technique. The painter’s family spent the summer of 1886 in St Ives, Cornwall, and the artist was often with them. Here, looking out towards the sea and beyond the vast expanse of sand in the foreground we see small figures of holiday-makers in their fashionable clothes and a number of beach huts. Forbes had studied in Paris. The influence of his time there can be seen here in his practice of painting outdoors (en plein air), his focus on modern life and the daring composition, which was influenced by Japanese art and contemporary photography.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the MGC/V&A Purchase Grant Fund and the Wills Fund, 1990

fields.additional_information: The orange and apple probably allude to the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge and original sin, the large bunch of grapes recalls the blood of Christ and the wine of the Eucharist, while cherries are the fruit of paradise. The painting was probably made in the Bruges area around 1500, and shows the influence of Hans Memling. It was probably intended for private devotion.
fields.label: The figures of the Virgin and Child are set before the so-called cloth of honour. One the ledge between the holy figures and the viewer lie fruits which symbolise Christ's role as the redeemer of humanity.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946

fields.additional_information: Small dots visible around the bread and the cherries on the picture surface were made when the artist transferred his preparatory drawing to the prepared panel, by pricking the lines of the cartoon and 'pouncing' charcoal through the holes. This technique made the production of replica images in an artist's workshop easier. Little is known about the artist, who was prominent in Bruges.
fields.label: Although the Holy Family - the Christ Child, Mary and Joseph - appear in this small picture in an everyday setting, the items on their table have religious meaning. The bread recalls the Last Supper and the Eucharist, its re-enactment celebrated by Christian worshippers.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: The Holy Family at a Meal

fields.additional_information: Having come to see the new-born Christ, the shepherds tentatively enter the presence of the Holy Family in the manger. The Virgin kneels before her child, and Joseph is shown as an elderly man praying in the background. A group of three angels has been included at the top of the composition. The colours in this image are jewel-like and the landscape is very finely painted. The image reflects the pioneering achievement by Flemish artists in the technique of oil painting which began to replace tempera painting across Europe. As in most images at the time, the stable, which appears as a grand but ruined building, forms a visual reference to the Temple of King Solomon in the Old Testament. This re-interpretation of the architecture was understood by believers to show the renewal of the old bond between God and the people through Christ.
fields.label: Having come to see the new-born Christ, the shepherds tentatively enter the presence of the Holy Family. The Virgin kneels before her child, and Joseph is shown as an elderly man praying in the background. A group of three angels has been included at the top of the composition.
fields.source: Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946

fields.additional_information: Straying from the story in the Old Testament, in this work of art not all the animals have a partner. Some pairs, like the swans, appear twice and Griffier also included imaginary creatures: two unicorns are trotting up the ramp to the Ark. The artist, who was born in Amsterdam, spent most of his career in England where he usually painted topographical views. This immense painting was probably commissioned from the artist by Sir John Trevelyan of Nettlecombe Court, Somerset, and it remained in the Great Hall at Nettlecombe for almost 300 years. The picture shows evidence of once being hit by a gunshot, while the circular cracks all over the paint surface result from regular impact during ball games.
fields.label: According to the Bible, God instructed Noah to build a vessel large enough to save his family and a pair of all of the world's animals from the Great Flood. Here, Jan Griffier depicted on a grand scale the gathering of all the animals onto the Ark, showing his skill as an animal painter.
fields.source: Purchased with the generals assistance of an anonymous benefactor, MGC/V&A Purchase Grant Fund, G.W.S. Melbuish Bequest, National Art - Collections Fund (now The Art Fund), Peter Blyth Fund, a private trust fund and the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1992

fields.label: Two angels are carefully supporting the muscular body of Christ, who has been taken off the cross, as is indicated by the wounds on his hands. The scene is shown in dramatic close-up and lighting, but has an overall clarity and calm. Francesco Trevisani, who had studied in Venice, settled in Rome in 1681 working for important patrons, including Pope Clement XI. Foreign travellers to Italy not only engaged with the classical and the Renaissance, they also took an interest in contemporary art. Trevisani's art would have been known to Grand Tourists through his church commissions, including his frescoes in the cathedral in Urbino.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the National Art-Collections Fund (now The Art Fund), 1968

fields.label: In 1834, when William James Müller was 24 years old, he left Bristol for a seven month sketching tour on the Continent. He travelled up the Rhine and reached the old university town of Heidelberg on the Neckar where he spent several days. Heidelberg was popular with German Romantics and British tourists. In this view the artist makes most of the low view across the water and Heidelberg's famous landmarks, including the castle which had been a picturesque ruin since the Thirty Years' War.
fields.source: Purchased 1923

fields.label: Barbara Hepworth was one of the first British artists to make Abstract art. Winged Figure is the model for the iconic aluminium sculpture she designed for John Lewis's on Oxford Street, London. It combines modern forms and materials in a sculpture that looks to a technological future. Pierced holes show the relationship between inside and outside. The inner surface texture was achieved using filler material for dented car panels. The threaded strings create tension between the centre and the wings.
fields.source: Loan, the Barbara Hepworth Estate

fields.label:
"I have a strong preference for primitive and elementary forms."
William Scott shifted between representational imagery and Abstraction throughout his career. Although he felt close to the traditions of Europe, he also felt an affinity with the American Mark Rothko. Black, Grey and Blue has a strong physical presence that was created by lighting patches of blue against shiny and matte shades of black.
fields.source: Given by the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery. 1978 (purchased by them through the Dyer Bequest Fund, 1961)

fields.label: Designed by Emile Gallé.
fields.source: Given by J. Stanley Clarke through the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1966.

fields.label: A country road between grassy banks and lined with trees leads the viewer's gaze diagonally into the picture towards a white building with a red roof on the right. A majestic tree rises above the scene in the centre of the picture. Beyond, the land drops and rises again in the background where a church and other buildings are silhouetted against the lightly clouded sky. Two women with white bonnets can be seen walking along the road. Although this is a complex composition, Sisley has captured a sense of the calm freshness of an early summer day. The picture's surface is animated through the use of visible brushstrokes and the figures' shadows are painted in purple. Sisley was born in Paris of English parents and lived in France all his life. He struggled throughout his life to sell his work, although he was promoted by several important dealers, including Paul Durand-Ruel who handled this picture in 1892.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund and Estate Duty exemption, 1972

fields.artist: Maker's Mark: ewer AB, bowl AB above an annulet [small ring], London
fields.label:
both bear a dedicatory inscription headed 'St Warborows'
The bowl is in the style of the shallow drinking cups which had been fashionable in the late 16th century and it may have been intended as a communion cup into which wine was poured from the ewer. However, it is unlikely that two non-matching wine flagons would have been given at the same time and so it is equally possible that the ewer and bowl were used in the ‘ablution' ritual in which the priest ceremonially washed his hands before celebrating communion. This ancient custom was revived in the early 1600s. The ewer, with its pear-shaped body and straight spout, is one of only five such ewers to be found in English churches.
fields.title_of_object: Ewer or "Skinker" and Shallow Bowl on Foot

fields.additional_information: Little is known of William Larkin's life, although for over a decade he worked for patrons connected with the royal court. In this portrait, the woman looks straight at the viewer, giving her an air of great confidence. But Elizabethan and Jacobean court portraiture emphasised the wealth and status of the sitter rather than their character. The embroidered flowers include heartsease, roses and thistles; the tendrils that link them are plaited braid stitches in metallic thread. The lace is Italian needlepoint and was part of a chemise worn under the bodice.
fields.label: William Larkin's detailed depiction of beautiful and expensive fabrics made him very popular with his aristocratic sitters. This young woman's low-cut embroidered bodice and long flowing hair were the height of fashion around 1615.
fields.source: Purchased 1969

fields.additional_information: Her body and gaze are cunningly turned in the direction of the soldier on the left, who shares the table with St Peter. In response, St Peter gestures towards himself as if astonished at the charge, implying that it is case of mistaken identity. The painting?s dramatic chiaroscuro (extreme contrasts of light and dark), the reflections of firelight on the soldier's armour, and the saint's frightened expression lend particular drama to the moment. This highly admired picture has been associated with the early work of the important Dutch artist Gabriel Metsu, although the question of attribution has not actually been resolved.
fields.label: The painting shows how sophisticated seventeenth-century artists had become in depicting complex emotions and relationships between figures. Inside a dark tavern a young woman points her finger to accuse the biblical figure St Peter, on the right, of being a follower of Christ.
fields.source: Purchased 1951

fields.additional_information: The figures represented are the popular saints Anthony Abbot, considered the founder of Christian monasticism, or monkhood, and credited with miraculous powers of healing, and Francis, who founded the Franciscan order in the thirteenth century. Unusually, the stigmata of St Francis (body marks corresponding to the crucifixion wounds of Jesus Christ) are pinpointed with tiny gold rays.
fields.label: This gold-ground panel has been attributed to Lorenzo di Bicci, the first known painter of an important Florentine artistic family which operated its workshop for over more than a century. This painting probably occupied the left side of a multi-panelled altarpiece, of which the remaining panels are lost or unidentified.
fields.source: Acquired before 1953

fields.label: This painting was commissioned by Horace Walpole and depicts his three friends George Augustus Selwyn, George James Williams and Richard, 2nd Lord Edgcumbe. It commemorates their holidays which Walpole organised twice a year at Strawberry Hill, his Gothic Revival villa. The books and papers, as well as the way in which the sitters appear to have been interrupted in their conversation, allude to their cultural aspirations, social standing and their famed 'wit'. Selwyn and Walpole had been on the Grand Tour. Walpole and the Edgcumbe family were patrons of Reynolds and all four men were involved in politics and public office. Nothing in this civilised group portrait betrays Williams' and Edgcumbe's well-known reputation for gambling and their wild life styles.
fields.source: FPM Schiller bequst, 1946

fields.label: In Francis Danby's opinion Norway 'was the country of Ossian, the most picturesque in the world. The artist visited in 1825 but seems not to have painted any Norwegian subjects in oil until after he moved to Switzerland in 1831. By that time his memory of place names appears to have let him down since no such place as Liensfiord exists: it has been suggested that Lifjord near Rutledal is intended.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the V & A Purchase Grant Fund and Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 2016

fields.label:
Although Hippolyte Adam is mainly known for his portraits and figure paintings, this view demonstrates his accomplishment as a landscape artist. The Hôpital Saint Louis is shown beyond the Canal Saint-Martin, which runs to the east of the Parisian Gare de l'Est. Founded in 1607, the hospital still functions today, although its setting is now built up and the hospital is no longer visible from the far side of the canal. The hills in the distance, traditionally quarried for their gypsum deposits used in plaster of Paris, now form part of the Parc des Buttes-Chaumont which was laid out in 1866-7.
There is a freshness in the observation of the morning light and a surety of touch in the use of near-black paint for the silhouetted figures by the Canal Saint-Martin. It links this work with a new approach to nature found across European landscape painting at this period.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the MGC/V&A Purchase Grant Fund and The Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1989
fields.title_of_object: L'Hôpital Saint Louis et les Buttes-Chaumont, Paris

fields.label: Tall, overgrown rocks reveal the large entrance of a cave. A group of men and women in local Italian costume have gathered outside it in the foreground. They are accompanied by their dogs and horse and seem to engage in a casual conversation. Others are making their way along the sandy road into the distance. To the 19th century spectator the scene would have suggested entertainingly dubious goings-on, such as smuggling. Thomas Barker was the most successful member of an artistic family which had settled in Bath in 1783. A local auctioneer, Charles Spackman, fostered his talent and paid for him to study in Italy from 1790 to 1793. This cavern scene, once known as 'The Bandits', was painted in Rome. Barker spent the rest of his career in Bath and although he was successful as a painter of portraits, rustic landscapes and genre scenes (everyday life), his popularity declined and he died in poverty.
fields.source: Presented by Sir Herbert Ashman, 1905
fields.title_of_object: Cavern Scene near Subiaco, with Figures

fields.label: Since his art foundation course Long had been experimenting with ephemeral forms of sculpture and gentle interventions in the landscape. The most instantaneous was to trace a path by rolling a snowball across the snow-covered Bristol Downs. For England Long picked daisies in a field, marking out the cross of the English flag. Today more than ever Long's reversible marks on the landscape have pointed resonance as we recognise the climate emergency caused by humanity.
fields.source: Gift, Arnolfini Collection Trust, 2000

fields.label: Bryan Wynter always stressed that his Abstract work was closely linked to nature. Forest Journey depicts a walk through the woods. The dynamic and explosive marks suggest light seen through trees - or the corner of an eye. Through the layering of black and colour, Wynter conveyed a depth of space that draws us into the heart of the forest.
fields.source: Purchased, 1961

fields.label: Salem was a brand of menthol cigarette: the green haze is the same colour as the packaging but also evokes the advert's rugged outdoor imagery. Richard Smith was curious about the way that advertising had hijacked rural imagery but his style is Abstract compared to Pop Art's collages of mass media images. The painted gestures of Salem soak into the canvas reminding us that the painting is an object.
fields.source: Gift, the Contemporary Art Society, 1962

fields.label: Aubrey Williams moved to London in 1954 where previous time spent with the indigenous Warao people of his native Guyana fed into his work. Williams felt an affinity with Shostakovich and like the composer combined different types of art: here skeletal forms from Warao mythology mix with the gestures of Abstract Expressionism. The 13th Symphony commemorates the murder of Ukrainian Jews in the Second World War.
fields.source: Given by the Commonwealth Education Trust through the Contemporary Art Society. 2015
fields.title_of_object: Shostakovich Symphony no 13, Opus 113 for Bass

fields.label: Howard Hodgkin painted representational pictures of emotional situations', often featuring his friends. Painting around the edge of the panel, Hodgkin created a box-like enclosure that suggests a room. Like the intimate portraits of women by Edouard Vuillard, Hodgkin layered surface pattern to blur the depth of the image as if we are viewing the scene through a window or doorway.
fields.source: Purchased, 1975

fields.label: Lucien Pissarro depicted his young wife, Esther, sitting in the shade of a tree in the garden of the family home. The turkeys, which give the painting its title, can be seen in the left foreground. The recreation of the dappled light shows the artist's interest in (Neo-)Impressionist techniques and their views of the roles of light and the human eye. Lucien Pissarro was taught to paint by his father, Camille Pissarro, and both artists were interested in Seurat's theory of the optical mixing of colour. Here, the brushstrokes keep each colour separate, achieving a vibrant effect in the lush foliage. The shadows on the ground appear purple. Lucien had moved to England in 1890 and later adopted British nationality. After his marriage to Esther in 1892, the couple spent over eight months in France.
fields.source: Given by Mrs A.M.T. Barrett (neé Marjorie Sherlock), 1972
fields.title_of_object: The Turkeys (OR Esther in the Garden, Eragny)

fields.label: Roderic O'Conor spent most of his career outside his native Ireland and was a friend of Paul Gauguin. He lived in France for over fifty years and painted his best work during the 1890s in Pont-Aven, Brittany. This unfinished picture, which is part of a series of seascapes O'Conor painted at the time, shows his working method: the composition sketched in with touches of thin, blue pigment, followed by the establishment of the colour and tone of the main features. The sky and sea were completed in vigorous strokes of thick paint (impasto). He preferred pure colour, and frequently contrasted complementary colours, as here with blue and orange. The crimson red of the rocky cliffs rising towards the right is used for its own sake as a colour. The lonely coast is portrayed as place of grandeur with a powerful physical presence.

According to the account in the Roman poet Ovid's work Metamorphoses, Andromeda, an Ethiopian princess, was chained to cliffs as a sacrifice to a ravaging sea monster, sent by the vengeful god Poseidon to terrorise the land. Her sensuous body dominates the composition and her liberator, Perseus, is only lightly delineated in the sky. He holds a shield with a Gorgon's head which will shortly turn the monster into stone. Moreau's subjects were exclusively taken from classical mythology or the bible. He painted with a sumptuous richness; his larger works have elaborately encrusted surfaces built-up from many layers of pigment. The poetry and imaginative power of his work particularly appealed to men of letters like the novelist Joris-Karl Huysmans. Moreau mentioned this picture in 1885, writing that the collector Paul Tesse owned a painting of Andromeda by him. Tesse's seal is indeed on the reverse.

fields.source: Photograph of the entry in the Churchwarden's Accounts of St Wherburgh's Church, recording Humphrey Brown's gift in 1621 of a Bristol Record Office.
fields.label: St Werburgh's Church possessed the finest collection of church plate of all the churches in Bristol. The four pieces shown here were acquired in the 1620s and are of particular note. The ewer and shallow bowl form a pair; the flagon, though in a different style, was given at the same time; the communion cup was given three years later but there seems little doubt that they were intended to form a cohesive group. As such, they constitute one of the earliest 'sets of communion plate in England.   '“This present yeare Anno 1621 Mr Humphry Browne merchant a bountifull benefactor and parishioner unto this church, did give unto the use of this P[aris]h church of St Warburg for ever, one Double guilt flagon of Silver waying thri Skore [three score, i.e. 60] ounces and halfe, one Silver skinker double guilt waying thirty six ounces and halfe, and one Silver bowle Double guilt waying twenty foure ounces and a quarter, for wch his munificence wee the parishioners doe wish him all [?] prosperitie and trew happiness."

fields.additional_information: This relief, which probably belonged to an ornate altarpiece containing scenes from the life of Christ, was carved in Brussels at the end of the fifteenth century and came into the collection from the Bristol church of St Augustine's, near the Cathedral.
fields.label: The scene shows Christ's body being placed into a tomb by Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus with the three Marys who had been present at the Crucifixion looking on.
fields.source: On loan from the Bristol Diocesan Board

fields.additional_information: n/a
fields.label: Joos van Cleve was a leading painter in Antwerp whose paintings of the Virgin and Child and Holy Family were so popular that many copies were painted. 'The Madonna of the Cherries' exists in several versions and this one was probably produced in his workshop under his close supervision
fields.source: Lent from a private collection

fields.additional_information: Charles holds a short partisan (staff) and behind him are the knightly accessories of gauntlets and helmet. He wears a collar of the type which came into fashion around 1605 and the long skirts worn by young children of both sexes. Robert Peake painted Charles's head and hands while his studio, as was common practice, completed the drapery and background. The paint was enriched with precious metals: silver (now darkened through age) was used in the stripes of the dress and gold leaf on the curtain.
fields.label: This is the earliest known portrait of the future Charles I. It was painted when he was just four or five years old, probably soon after he had been created Duke of York in January 1605, during celebrations for Twelfth Night.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the National Art-Collections Fund (now The Art Fund) and the Victoria & Albert Museum Purchase Grant Fund, 1974.
fields.title_of_object: Charles I when Duke of York

fields.additional_information: The unknown painter of this flower piece was probably influenced by Jan Davidsz de Heem, one of the best known of seventeenth century still life painters whose work could be found on the walls of private homes and residences. The painted blooms represented luxury since flower gardens were the preserve of the wealthy. Tulips, which were first introduced into Europe from Turkey, were particularly popular and valuable. This tulip's prominent broken stem reminds us of the fleeting beauty of flowers and encourages us to reflect on the transience of life itself.
fields.label: The flowers in this painting would not have bloomed at the same time, but Dutch and Flemish artists often combined plants from several seasons. The vase is filled with irises, tulips, roses and holly with berries. Viewers would have understood their symbolic meaning. The tulip, for example, was associated with vanity and arrogance.
fields.source: The Bequest of Alan Frederick Penraven, 1922.

fields.additional_information: It is unknown if this rocky landscape with a rapidly flowing river was based on a place that Jacob van Ruisdael visited. Alternatively it has been suggested that views such as this one may have been inspired by the drawings of the Amsterdam landscape painter Allart van Everdingen, who visited Scandinavia in 1644 and made studies of mountainous landscapes with torrents and waterfalls. Ruisdael?s ability to paint highly atmospheric, ?romantic? landscapes was the reason for his popularity throughout the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
fields.label: In this upright format, the rich, dark and dense greens and browns of the trees and landscape are set against the towering and luminous clouds whose greys are reflected and repeated in the ever falling water.
fields.source: Presented by the National Art - Collections Fund (now The Art Fund), from the bequest of Ernest E.. Cook of Bath, 1955

fields.additional_information: N/A
fields.label: In this expansive Brazilian landscape five enslaved Africans are working the manioc (cassava) mill with a Dutch overseer or possibly the mill owner standing to the right Frans Post was one of very few artists to accompany and observe the Dutch East India Company's colonial efforts in South America from 1637 to 1644. To modern viewers his depiction of slavery as a seeming normality is highly controversial, but Post's paintings offer valuable historic insight into 17th-century European attitudes.
fields.source: Private Collection

fields.additional_information: Above, a multitude of angels illuminates the landscape with heavenly light. The impressive composition has been related to another image of the Annunciation to the Shepherds (about 1630) by Pieter van Laer (1599 - about 1642). Although it is not known for certain that Nicolaes Berchem visited Italy, from the 1650s he worked in an exclusively Italianate style. He became a leading exponent of the Dutch Italianates, that is, artists who were inspired by the Italian landscape and light and incorporated them in their pictures.
fields.label: The Gospel of St Luke in the Bible's New Testament recounts how an angel announced the news of Christ's birth to local shepherds. Nicholas Berchem shows the shepherds staring in awe at the angel, although their animals remain placid.
fields.source: Purchased 1954

fields.additional_information: According to the Book of Numbers in the Bible?s Old Testament, the Israelites are on their journey out of Egypt. In the Le Brun?s painting, although some individuals flee, the more obedient men and women turn towards the bronze serpent, because 'everyone that is bitten, when he looketh upon it shall live'. According to Christian teaching, this episode anticipates Christians' acceptance of Christ?s crucifixion as their redeemer. The expressive gestures and facial expressions and the choice of bright blues and yellows in this painting are characteristic of Charles Le Brun, who was a dominant figure in seventeenth-century classicist French painting.
fields.label: This dramatic, almost theatrical scene shows an episode from the Old Testament. In the wilderness, the Israelites are being attacked by a plague of fiery serpents sent by God in punishment for their sinfulness. To save them, Moses exhorts them to look at a bronze serpent he has erected.
fields.source: Presented by the Rt Hon, Lewis Fry, 1905

fields.medium: Oil on canvas laid on panel & oil on panel
fields.additional_information:
The English merchant Paul Withypool (died 1547) may have commissioned this altarpiece from Antonio Solario while he was on business in Italy. A cartellino, a painted piece of parchment, implores the Virgin to intercede for his soul.

In the centre the Holy Family are depicted with the donor Withypool inside a simple chamber with two windows opening the view on to a distant landscape. Clutching a goldfinch, symbolic of ?the Passion?, the Christ child lies on a marble slab which intentionally reminds the viewer of both a tomb and an altar. The canvas forms the centre of a triptych, an arrangement of three related images. On the wing to the left, Saint Catherine is shown with her attribute, the spiked wheel upon which she was martyred. On the panel to the right, Saint Ursula carries her attribute, an arrow, with which she was martyred.
fields.label: The English merchant Paul Withypool (died 1547) may have commissioned this altarpiece from Antonio Solario while he was on business in Italy. In the centre the Holy Family are depicted with Withypool inside a simple chamber with two windows opening the view on to a distant landscape. Clutching a goldfinch, symbolic of 'the Passion', the Christ child lies on a marble slab. In the right bottom corner a painted piece of parchment reads: "Orate pro anima Pauli Withipol” (Pray for the Soul of Paul Withypool).
fields.source: Centre panel purchased with the assistance of the National Art Collections Furid, 1937 Wing panck Tent by the National Gallery, London

fields.additional_information:
According to the Roman poet Ovid, Narcissus was an irresistibly attractive young man. When the nymph Echo fell in love with him, Narcissus rejected her. Nemesis, the goddess of justified revenge, punished Narcissus by making him fall in love with his own reflection when he stooped to take a drink of water. He would perish from his unrequited love. 
Painted on a miniaturist scale, this panel is believed to originate from the Umbrian region of Italy.
fields.label: Italian artists often depicted this classical story of Narcissus' destructive self-love. In this small composition a young man, attired for hunting with his dogs beside him, gazes at his own reflection in a fountain.
fields.source: The Bequest of Peter Grenville Temple, 1979

fields.additional_information: The scene takes place before a low wicker fence in a garden with delicate small plants and flowers. The background is dominated by tall mountains. The landscape background is a typical feature of Venetian devotional paintings of the early sixteenth century. Its intimate size indicates that the painting was made for a domestic setting rather than a church. This painting is usually associated with Girolamo da Santacroce, a Venetian artist who was influenced by Giovanni Bellini.
fields.label: According to the New Testament, in the aftermath of the Crucifixion Mary Magdalen mistakes the risen Christ for a gardener. He is depicted in this small composition on the right, holding a hoe. Mary Magdalen has fallen to her knees in honour of the Lord, although he urges her not to touch him: 'Noli me tangere'.
fields.source: Presented by Alfred de Pass in memory of Nora de Pass, 1936
fields.title_of_object: Noli Me Tangere', Christ Appearing to the Magdalen

fields.label: Painted in broad brushstrokes, Couture has captured the head and shoulders of a young, dark haired girl in traditional Italian folk costume. She has turned her face to the right and gazes into the distance. Her long coral bead necklace with its gilt cross pendant stands out from her white shirt. Striving to achieve recognition and success at the Paris Salon, Thomas Couture produced a number of large, complex compositions in the grand tradition. By contrast, this more intimate painting demonstrates the more spontaneous side of his nature. It is one of a number of studies which Couture made of the strolling Italian players who passed by his home at Villiers-le-Bel in 1877. Couture was a popular and influential teacher in Paris and encouraged his pupils to retain the qualities of the sketch, such as pure colour and fresh brushwork, in their finished paintings. Among his pupils were Edouard Manet, Pierre Puvis de Chavannes, and several American artists.
Designed by Henri Muller at Croismar [near Nancy]
fields.source: Given by G.P.R. Dooley, 1993

fields.additional_information: It is one of a series of similar portraits which date from 1525 or 1526, and some of these are accompanied by a pendant portrait of Katharina, suggesting that the present picture may also have been one of a pair. Luther?s expression is restrained and calm, lending the sitter gravitas and legitimizing his marriage and his position as a leader of the European Reformation.
fields.label: Lucas Cranach worked for forty-nine years in Wittenburg where he was at the centre of th Protstant movement and where he enjoyed a close friendship with Martin Luther. He painted this closely observed portrait in 1525, the year of Luther's marriage to Katharina von Bora.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M Schiller, 1946

fields.additional_information:
The minutely observed portrait of a young woman in sixteenth century dress subtly focusses the viewer?s attention on her light skin and fine features as well as the white fabric emerging from the slits in her black sleeves.

Anne Stuart was married to her relative Robert Stuart, Lord d'Aubigny, Maréchal of France, and was a lady-in-waiting to the French Queen Eleanor (1498 ? 1558). Anne?s portrait has been dated to the period 1533-36 and is one of a series by Corneille de Lyon and his workshop, which was produced when Corneille was painter to the Queen. Although the inscription on the Bristol version is very old, it is probably a later addition. There are two other versions of the portrait, one of them in the Louvre in Paris.
fields.label: The minutely observed portrait of a young woman in sixteenth-century dress subtly focuses the viewer's attention on her light skin and fine features as well as the white fabric emerging through the sleeves.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: Portrait of a Lady, said to be Anne Stuart, Maréchale d'Aubigny

fields.medium: Oil on canvas laid on panel
fields.artist: Willem van de VELDE, the Younger
fields.additional_information: The Northern Netherlands split from Spanish rule during the Eighty Years War, which ended in 1648. Rapidly, the Dutch Republic became one of Europe?s leading maritime nations with a global trading network. Naturally, the seascape was a popular genre in Dutch art, often suggesting a symbolic meaning behind the realism of the waves and sky. Like many of Willem van de Velde's atmospheric scenes of calm seas with shipping, this painting probably dates from the 1650s when the artist was still in his twenties and living in Amsterdam. Van de Velde's marine paintings were particularly prized and influential in England where the artist lived from about 1672.
fields.label: In this tranquil beach scene, the Dutch marine artist Willem van de Velde has sensitively observed the grey-blue sky, the effects of aerial perspective and the reflections of light in pools of water on the sandy shore. Each vessel is carefully placed in order to create a balanced composition.
fields.source: Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: A 'Smalschip' with Sail Set at Anchor Close to Shore, and a 'Boier' Laid Ashore

fields.medium: Oil on canvas transferred from panel
fields.additional_information: The adult gravitas with which the child is portrayed reflects the importance of his status. Children often kept goldfinches as pets but the bird he holds also symbolised ?the Passion? (the events leading up to Christ?s crucifixion) and was a talisman against evil. The artist was originally thought to be Giovanni Ambrogio de Predis (circa 1455-after 1508), but this was later questioned and the attribution became Milanese School. In 2011, it was reattributed to Giovanni Marco D'Oggiono who worked in Milan and was influenced by Leonardo da Vinci (1452 ? 1519).
fields.label: The finely dressed small boy in this portrait is Francesco Maria Sforza (1491-1512), son of Gian Galeazzo and Isabella d'Aragona. He was nicknamed 'il duchetto' (the little duke) as he became titular Duke of Milan in 1494 when he was only about three years old.
fields.source: Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: Portrait of Francesco Maria Sforza, known as 'Il Duchetto'

fields.additional_information: The intense colour, small scale and attention to detail are reminiscent of book illuminations. In fact, a similar composition in Cleveland Museum of Art, also by Timoteo Viti, is a full-page miniature executed in tempera (pigment mixed in a water-soluble medium) on vellum (parchment made from calf skin). Timoteo Viti worked mainly in Urbino, carrying out several commissions for its cathedral.
fields.label: This delicate panel painting depicts Christ praying in the Garden of Gethsemane on the night before his crucifixion, while his disciples sleep. On the winding road which leads to the distant city of Jerusalem, a group of soldiers, led by Judas, are coming to arrest Christ.
fields.source: Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946

fields.label: In 1959, Peter Lanyon took up gliding to get a more complete knowledge of the landscape'. The Cubist forms of his early work gave way to the freer gestures and frenetic circling of High Moor, which place the viewer amongst the wind and sea. He nevertheless claimed to artist Alan Davie that he ‘always [had) a clear image in my mind before starting' a painting.
fields.source: Given by the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1978 (purchased by them through the Dyer Bequest Fund, 1961)

fields.label:
Art Nouveau was an influential style in the visual arts which developed in 19th century Europe. It is found particularly in the applied arts, graphics and illustration and was inspired by nature. Characteristic are sinuous curving forms and line. Painting styles such as Symbolism shared close ties with Art Nouveau.
Emile Gallé was one of the most important French glass designers and an outstanding exponent of Art Nouveau. He worked particularly with cameo glass. This technique involves building up two or more layers of different coloured glass and then cutting away the layers to create the design. All the vases on display here use this technique.
Vase Designe
Nancy in France became a centre for the manufacture of this style of glass with makers such as Gallé and the Daum Brothers based there from the 1880s.

Boudin has captured the maze of masts and rigging along the quaysides of a Northern French harbour on a wet, chilly and windy day. The grey sky and leaden sea are rendered with a sense of constant movement, animated by breaking up the water's surface into single brushstrokes. The perspective is focussed on a ship in the middle distance, thereby closing off the background beyond and keeping the picture space narrow. Boudin was born near the harbour at Le Havre on the Normandy coast and this area was the inspiration for most of his atmospheric art. He had the gift of communicating his enthusiasm for working direct from nature to other artists and painted with Courbet, Whistler and the young Monet and his influence on the latter was crucial.
fields.source: Bequest of Miss Millicent Wedmore, 1965

fields.additional_information:
Thank you to everyone who donated to The Rialto Bridge conservation appeal, without whom re-display of this work of art would not have been possible. With particular thanks to Simon Baker, Jonathan & Harriet Bradley, Sarah Kenny, David Speller, The Michael Le Marchant Charitable Trust, The Veneziana Fund (from Pizza Express customers' contributions), as well as the many other donors to Bristol Museums Development Trust who kindly supported the appeal.
Bristol Museums Development Trust
Helping treasure to shine
fields.label: This quintessential Venetian scene, with the Rialto Bridge spanning the Grand Canal and gondolas in the foreground, is a perfect example of the view paintings popular with English grand tourists of the eighteenth century. The Rialto Bridge, with shops and stalls spanning the arch, was already a famous landmark in Venice, and provided the only foot passage across the Grand Canal. In this painting it stands out against the luminous sky and serves as a backdrop to the busy traffic of boats going about their business on the main waterway through the city. This picture is also highly significant as a key work by Michele Marieschi, an important Venetian vedutista, whose monogram appears on one of the barrels to the right. For some years it was the only work recognised as having been signed by him, and it has therefore helped with the reconstruction of Marieschi's career.
fields.source: Presented by Alfred Aaron de Pass, 1936

fields.label: Ann Leyborne Leyborne wears a luxurious blue silk dress and a very unusual adornment made of strands of braided or twisted silk around her long neck. Costume historians consider this the only known portrait showing such an item, which has no name. She lifts strands of the silk towards her posy of flowers, kept fresh in a bosom bottle (a small vessel containing water). Ann Popham became the wife of William Leyborne Leyborne in 1763 and portraits of both of them were painted, probably to celebrate the marriage. This painting was incorrectly inscribed during the 19th century when descendants had assumed the surname of Leyborne-Popham.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the National Art-Collections Fund (now The Art Fund), 1956

fields.label: This highly theatrical painting was commissioned from de Loutherbourg by the engraver James Fitter, who toured it around the country and published a print after it. The subject is a celebrated incident of the Napoleonic wars and took place on 21 July 1801, when a British force captured the French ship La Chevrette at Brest in Brittany. A boarding party attack the prow of the Chevrette, men clamber on board and others are already engaged in fighting. Billowing smoke and strong lighting add to the sense of drama, chaos and action. Philippe Jacques de Loutherbourg was a highly successful French artist who settled in England in 1771. He specialised in dramatic landscapes as well as scenes of contemporary and historic naval events. De Loutherbourg was also famed for his stage set designs and stage effects using colour, lighting and sound.
fields.source: Bequest of Charles Bowles Hare, 1911
fields.title_of_object: The Cutting-Out of the French Corvette La Chevrette, July 21, 1801

fields.label: A group of men and women have set up camp in a wooded landscape under a gnarled tree. Contemporary viewers would have identified the figures as travellers or ‘gypsies'. Morland specialised in this subjects like this, romanticising the life of those on the fringes of society. The landscape itself appears to reflect an untamed wildness, but this ‘naturalism'is carefully staged and the composition owes its layout, colours and rendering of detail to Dutch 17th century art, which had become very popular in Britain during the 18th century.
fields.source: Purchased, 1968

fields.label:
"Drawing is a way to get what's in the brain out.'
Tala Madani moved to America from Iran when she was 13 and has said that her difficulty learning English attracted her to art. The way Madani combines the language of Abstraction with the figurative shares something with Roger Hilton's quest to reinvent figuration'. Her work is populated only by men, who seem to be caricatures but perhaps they are reflections of our own anxieties in the post-9/11 world.
fields.source: Presented by the Art Fund under Art Fund International, 2011

fields.label: Auerbach has painted at his studio near Mornington Crescent since 1954. He attended David Bomberg's night class at Borough Poly where the older artist introduced him to the idea of the spirit in the mass' as a way to paint atmosphere. Auerbach's painting reinforces the impressions of the eye (the stupid organ') with those of the other senses, especially touch. He never paints outdoors but sketches on the spot. The expressionist zigzags of architecture and sky are a kind of visual shorthand, based on his memory of place.
fields.source: Accepted in lieu of Inheritance Tax by HM Government and allocated to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery 2015

fields.label: Against the bare dark background and the sombre colours of a court room and its bored personnel, the despair and anguish of a young woman standing in the dock are emphasised. She covers her face in her hands while her lower body, clad in a red dress, clearly shows her advanced pregnancy. At the beginning of the 20th century Forain turned to painting this relatively new subject: the French law courts and the ordinary people caught up in a complex legal system. Using dramatic lighting, facial expression and gestures to great effect, the painter's sympathies are obviously with the unmarried mother.
