Designed by Emile Gallé.
fields.source: Purchased, 1966

fields.label: Designed by Emile Gallé [whose signature can be seen on the lake forming the landscspe],
fields.source: Purchased, 1962

fields.label: Vase Designed by Daum Frères.
fields.source: Purchased, 1966.

fields.label: Here, Eva Gonzales chose a scene of contemporary life, but deliberately made a narrative reading of this painting impossible. This is a scene, but it does not give the spectator any clues to an overall story. In front of a tall tree in the background Jeanne Gonzalès, who often modelled for her sister, is seated on a donkey in a fashionable dress. She gazes past the viewer, while Henri Guérard, the artist's husband, looks on. After Eva's sudden death aged only thirty-four, Jeanne and Henri married. The unfinished painting was found in the artist's studio after her death, and the area around the man's jacket is unresolved. It clearly shows the influence of Edouard Manet, who became Eva Gonzales' teacher after she worked as a model for him. Donkey Ride' is the only work by Gonzalès, who is one of a number of female Impressionists, in a public collection in Great Britain.
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of Alfred Daber, 1966, and conserved with the help of the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery

fields.artist: Maker's mark: F over W, London
fields.label: Dedicatory inscription in the same band as those on ewer and bowl

fields.additional_information: The identity of the north Netherlandish 'Master of Alkmaar' is uncertain, although he may have been Cornelis Buys the Elder, who worked in Alkmaar between 1490 and 1524. Art historians have described his figures as 'doll-like', which may be seen here in the Christ child and the musical cherubs.
fields.label: In this image St Anne, mother of the Virgin Mary, hands Christ a nut, and a walnut lies on the bench between them. In the fourth century St Augustine had explained the symbolism of the walnut: the outer green case was the flesh of Christ, the shell the wood of his cross, and the kernel his divine nature.
fields.source: The Bequest of F.P.M. Schiller, 1946
fields.title_of_object: Madonna and Child with Saint Anne

fields.additional_information: The inscription tells us that this young man was nineteen years of age when Cornelis de Zeeu painted his portrait in 1565. This was the year in which the artist came to England from the Netherlands to work, like many continental European painters seeking the welcoming market for portraiture in Tudor England.
fields.label: In this small portrait Cornelis de Zeeu has recorded a young man's features carefully, noting even his soft, sparse moustache. His large, expressive eyes make him seem rather serious, and the close 'cropping' of the portrait intensifies his gaze.
fields.source: The Bequest of Peter Grenville Temple, 1979.

fields.additional_information: Scenes like this which ridiculed or negatively portrayed country folk were popular with the urban clientele of Dutch seventeenth century artists. The immoral behaviour, which also included the depiction of unmeasured drinking, served as an example of how not to behave. Jan Steen was a prolific Dutch artist who painted portraits, genre scenes, religious and mythological subjects.
fields.label: Although this painting has been called a kitchen interior it is more likely an outer room of a tavern where a hunter, who has been out wildfowling, is taking refreshment. He makes a lewd gesture towards the serving maid and the man in the shadows behind laughs.
fields.source: On loan from a private collection.

fields.additional_information: This painting is considered to be a mature work of the artist who specialised in this genre. It includes a variety of objects and foods which would have been familiar in the middle class homes of Dutch burghers: an engraved silver goblet, pewter vessels and plates, a large ham stuck with cloves. The image is enlivened with details such as the rumpled table-cloth, a broken glass and scattered nutshells. The symbolism of Dutch seventeenth century still life is not always easy to interpret and the objects on the table are unlikely to have had a single meaning. Often, though, these pictures remind the viewer of the decline of all worldly things.
fields.label: Pieter Claesz's masterful depiction of foods and everyday objects arranged on a table is a perfect example of Dutch still life painting. The single light source is somewhere beyond the upper left corner of the composition, atmospherically highlighting the differing textures and materials in the picture.
fields.source: Purchased, 1951

fields.additional_information: The Roman artist Pietro da Cortona has centred the large composition around the precious travel chest being raided in the immediate foreground. He arranged the figures in an elliptical composition around it, with Rachel sitting on a camel's saddle on the right where the idols are actually hidden. Cardinal Francesco Barberini commissioned many works, including this one, from Pietro da Cortona, the pre-eminent painter of the Roman Baroque. Laban Seeking his Idols once hung together with its pendant, the Marriage of Jacob and Rachel (now in the Louvre), at the Palazzo Barberini, Rome.
fields.label: According to the book of Genesis in the Old Testament, Jacob served his uncle Laban to win in marriage his cousins Leah and Rachel. When Jacob and his wives departed for Canaan, Rachel stole her father's idols (religious statuettes). Laban pursued them. This painting shows him searching through one of the chests for the idols while Jacob holds open the lid.
fields.source: Presented by the Rt Hon, Lewis Fry, 1905

fields.additional_information: According to the New Testament, the Holy Family fled from Bethlehem to Egypt fearing that the infant Christ would be murdered by King Herod's soldiers. In this composition Joseph leads the donkey, and Mary leans protectively over the child. A putto, a chubby winged child, holds out an apple, a reference to the Tree of Life in the Garden of Eden and indicating Christ's role as the new Adam. The quiet drama of the scene is created by chiaroscuro illumination (extreme contrasts of light and dark).
fields.label: This important work by Il Cerano, also known as Giovanni Battista Crespi, considered the greatest Milanese painter of the seventeenth century, was rediscovered in 1958. The biblical figures, Joseph and Mary with the Christ Child on a donkey, are depicted in near life-size and appear to proceed out of the picture into the viewer's space.
fields.source: Purchased with assistance from the National Art - Collections Fund (now The Art Fund) 1958

fields.additional_information: N/A
fields.label: The New Testament parable of the Prodigal Son illustrates the theme of forgiveness by telling how a son, having squandered his wealth, returned shamefully to his home where his father forgave and welcomed him. In a picture space that seems to unite an interior with a landscape view, the welcome takes places in the left background of the composition. More prominently in the foreground food is being prepared and served. This painting is based on a composition signed by Jacopo Bassano and his son Francesco (held by Galleria Doria Pamphilj, Rome).
fields.source: Purchased with the assistance of the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery, 1958
fields.title_of_object: The Return of the Prodigal Son

fields.additional_information: The picture is very fine and smoothly finished, and the textures of the pearls, fabrics and skin have a luminous sheen. The painted surface seems denser and more opaque than in many works associated with the artist Carpaccio, to whom this work was traditionally attributed. X-ray analysis has revealed a pentimento (change of design) where the artist had blocked in the sitter's right shoulder, but subsequently painted over it to alter the outline. Possible under-drawing is showing through in the area of the mouth.
fields.label: The identity of the lady in this bust-length portrait is unknown, although her wealth is indicated by her richly embroidered costume and the numerous pearls. The picture is a fine example of the conventions of Italian Renaissance portraiture, such as a plain background and clarity of form.
fields.source: The Bequest of FP.M. Schiller, 1946

fields.label: This atmospheric landscape is dominated by the imposing ruins of the watchtower of Malghera on the right, which was once part of a medieval fortification outside Venice. Under a blue sky and beyond the tower and some fishermen's houses lie the foothills of the Alps. But overall Bellotto's scene is a fantasy composition, a so-called capriccio. Contemporary viewers knew that Venice was one of the highlights on the European Grand Tour and Italian artists, including Bellotto and his famous uncle Canaletto, catered for their fascination with this unique city. Interestingly, the splendour of its highly recognisable architecture is here replaced by the calm surrounding countryside.
fields.source: Accepted by HM Government in lieu of Inheritance Tax and allocated to Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, 1988

fields.label:
This full-length portrait of William Henry Cavendish-Bentinck, 3rd Duke of Portland was commissioned by the City of Bristol after the Duke was made High Steward in 1786. It hung in the Mansion House in Queen Square until the Bristol Riots in 1831 when the building was destroyed by fire. Standing by a classical column, gazing into the distance, CavendishBentinck is shown in his ducal red velvet and ermine robes. The scene opens in the left background to reveal a dramatically clouded sky.
Like many aristocrats of his day, the Duke had undertaken the Grand Tour, visiting Italy, Germany and Poland. He would have welcomed and understood the classical allusions artists like the young, Bristol-born Thomas Lawrence used in their paintings.
fields.source: Civic painting, formally transferred 2008
fields.title_of_object: William Henry Cavendish-Bentinck, 3rd Duke of Portland

fields.label: Portraits of valuable horses and favourite pets were regularly painted during the 18th century and George Stubbs was a key figure in this area of British art. Here, a dog and carefully groomed horse have been placed in an elegant parkland setting. The partially clouded sky is lit by warm sunshine and together with the composition's low viewpoint this helps to glorify the animals. Nothing in the serene scene hints directly to the dramatic background story and the painting's link with the wider history of the British Empire. The dog Trim was described as a common cur' which had originally been a stray living on an estate in Jamaica. One night, his barking alerted the sleeping estate owner that an enslaved African had crept into his with a dagger intending to murder him. Trim was brought back to England, and later buried under a tree in the avenue of the family's house near Winchester.
fields.source: Private Collection

fields.label: Victor Pasmore's experiments with material, colour and form led him to treat his paintings like sculptures. His use of modern, everyday materials like plywood was a move away from traditional marble or bronze and an attempt to avoid the materials symbolizing or representing anything but themselves.
fields.source: Presented by the Friends of Bristol Art Gallery through the Dyer Bequest Fund with the assistance of the Gulbenkian Foundation, 1978

fields.label: These works show the artist combining Modernist gestural painting with traditional Indo-Persian miniature motifs. Bloody handprints and opaque drips of viscous red cover the paper. Closer examination reveals delicate blossoms emerging from the sticky crimson smears. The series is Qureshi's response to a terrible tragedy that took place in Pakistan in 2010.
fields.source: Presented by the Art Fund, under Art Fund International
